SEARCH
Package algorithms.disjointSets

Class DisjointForest<T>

java.lang.Object
algorithms.disjointSets.DisjointForest<T>
Type Parameters:
T - parameter type for the nodes to hold as data
public class DisjointForest<T> extends Object
An "all-in-one" class to handle the disjoint set methods and the nodes in a disjoint forest of trees. The disjointSet representation has a path compression operation internal to findSet method which makes subsequent membership disjointSet queries faster. implementation follows that in Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein Introduction to Algorithms who include references in chapter notes, specifically Tarjan 1999 class notes for COS 423 Princeton University.
Author:
nichole

  • Method Details

    • makeSet

      public DisjointForest.RootedTreeDisjointSet<T> makeSet(DisjointSet2Node<T> x)
      make a set out of the given node and add it to the internal forest. runtime complexity is O(1).
      Parameters:
      x - disjoint set mode
      Returns:
      a new set composed of only x

    • findSet

      public DisjointSet2Node<T> findSet(DisjointSet2Node<T> x)
       find the set representative for the given node.  As a side effect,
 also updates x and all of it's ancestors with the found result so that
 they directly point to the top most parent and subsequent lookups are
 faster (this is path compression).
 runtime complexity:
     the method uses iteration.  
     if we represent x_height as the number of nodes between x's tree 
     root and x, we have 2 times x_height iterations of statements,
 so O(x_height).   With path compression here, the amoritzed
 worst-case running time is Θ(α(n)) where α is the inverse Ackermann 
 function.  
 
 The inverse Ackermann function is α(n) = min{k : A_k(1) ≥ n}.
 For most purposes, α(n) = O(1) so then the amoritized running time is O(1).
      Parameters:
      x - disjoint set node
      Returns:
      top-most parent in ancestry of x.

    • union

      public DisjointSet2Node<T> union(DisjointSet2Node<T> x, DisjointSet2Node<T> y)
      append the shorter list onto the end of the longer list. The amortized runtime complexity would be O(1) due to the path compression in findSet but we are moving nodes between sets so the worse case runtime complexity is O(n) for this context.
      Parameters:
      x - disjoint set x
      y - disjoint set y
      Returns:
      the union of x and y

    • unionChooseY

      public DisjointSet2Node<T> unionChooseY(DisjointSet2Node<T> x, DisjointSet2Node<T> y)
      Compress the paths in x and y and set the parent to be y. \ * The amortized runtime complexity is O(1) due to the path compression in findSet. The method is also known as "union-find" because it uses findSet as the first steps before link.
      Parameters:
      x - disjoint set x
      y - disjoint set y
      Returns:
      the reference to the union of x and y as x or y, preferring y if x==y

    • getTrees

      public Map<DisjointSet2Node<T>,DisjointForest.RootedTreeDisjointSet<T>> getTrees()
      Returns:
      the trees

    • connectedComponents

      public static List<gnu.trove.set.TIntSet> connectedComponents(SimpleLinkedListNode[] adjList)
      given the adjacency list of a graph, return the disjoint connected components. implemented from pseudocode in Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein Introduction To Algorithms.
      Parameters:
      adjList - graph adjacency list
      Returns:
      the connected components as a list of the disjoint sets of vertex numbers.
